creator: jeremias@apache.org
text:
Manuel,

don't worry, this is absolutely great! These test cases will help us improve 
quality in the long term and also help keep track of all the problems. I just 
hope noone expects us to fix all this in very short order. Especially the fact 
that you already provide very short test cases in the right format helps 
tremendously!

Similar to Bugs #36014 and #36018 I found the cause of the problem but 'what's
the fix'? The cause is simple - the leader-pattern-width property is defined as
having a percentage based of type LengthBase.CONTAINING_BOX. But in
LengthBase.getBaseLength() the switch statement doesn't handle that case =>
error message.

For "leader-pattern-width" and "leader-width" the spec says: Percentages refer
to the inline-progression-dimension of content-rectangle of parent area.

So I looked at the code and thought a statement like:
    parentFO.getLayoutDimension(PercentBase.BLOCK_IPD).intValue();
should do the trick. But that is the code used in the case of percent base set
to LengthBase.BLOCK_WIDTH. That means this should return the IPD of the
containing block which may not be the same as the parent area as the parent area
could be an inline area.

So how do I get to the IPD of the parent area?

text:
As I said earlier, the big deal with all the percentages is that the whole 
mechanism should be revised as is hinted at in the Wiki under "FO Tree":
http://wiki.apache.org/xmlgraphics-fop/FOPProjectTasks

See also a thread earlier this year:
http://marc.theaimsgroup.com/?t=110630668800003&r=1&w=2

The question you state is part of the problem. Someone really has to sit down 
and find out how to do this properly. What are the requirements? What are all 
the different cases? What's the best way to implement it so it stays easy to 
understand. Trying to fix single problems here and there won't do any good in 
the long run IMO.

Sorry, I didn't realize it was "that badly" broken as indicated in the e-mail
thread you pointed out. And obviously in that case a local fix won't do any good.
